Situation1: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Situation2: A patient with a common illness like strep throat has come to the clinic for a check-up.
Story:
I glanced at my phone, seeing a text from Mia: “Which night are we having our date? I’m free all week!” I smiled, picturing her excitement. We’d both been so busy lately, and I knew how much she valued our time together. I wanted to make it special, to show her she was my priority. But as I slipped my phone back into my pocket, I heard a soft cough from the exam room. My next patient, a young woman with a sore throat, waited for me. I scanned her chart—classic strep symptoms. She looked anxious, hoping for quick relief. I knew she expected me to listen carefully, prescribe the right medication, and reassure her.

As I washed my hands, my mind tugged in two directions. Mia’s hopeful message replayed in my head, but so did the patient’s need for my full attention. I felt the weight of both roles pressing on me—wanting to be the attentive boyfriend Mia deserved, and the thorough, compassionate doctor my patient needed. I took a deep breath, heart pounding, caught between the promise of a perfect evening and the responsibility in front of me, unsure which demand to answer first.
